official-title.#text:
To amend the Older Americans Act of 1965 to develop and test an expanded and advanced role for
			 direct care workers who provide long-term services and supports to older
			 individuals in efforts to coordinate care and improve the efficiency of
			 service delivery.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Improving Care for Vulnerable Older Citizens through Workforce Advancement Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Improving Care for Vulnerable Older Citizens through Workforce Advancement Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

found that 34 percent of
			 Americans 60 and older reported needing assistance performing Activities
			 of Daily Living.

text.#text:
As of 2012, more than 41,000,000 Americans are age 65 or older. More than 75 percent of them
			 suffer from chronic conditions which require person-centered, coordinated
			 care that helps them to live in a home- or community-based setting. In
			 2012, the

term.#tail:
) provide an estimated 70 to 80 percent of the paid hands-on long-term care and personal assistance
			 received by elders and people with disabilities or other chronic
			 conditions in the United States. These workers help their clients bathe,
			 dress, and negotiate a host of other daily tasks. They are a lifeline for
			 those they serve, as well as for families and friends struggling to
			 provide quality care.

text.#text: Direct-care workers (referred to in this section as

Eldercare and disability services positions account for nearly one-third of the 18,000,000 health
			 care jobs in the United States. The direct-care workforce alone accounts
			 for more than 4,000,000 jobs, expected to add 1,600,000 new positions by
			 2020.

The majority of DCWs are now employed in home- and community-based settings, and not in
			 institutional settings such as nursing care facilities or hospitals. By
			 2020, home- and community-based DCWs are likely to outnumber facility
			 workers by more than 2 to 1.

quote.#tail:
, called for new models of care delivery and coordination, and dedicated a chapter to the central
			 importance of the direct-care workforce in a
quote.#text: Re-tooling for an Aging America: Building the Health Care Workforce

text.#text: A 2008 Institute of Medicine report, entitled

An Institute of Medicine report on the future of nursing, released in October of 2010, recommended
			 nurses should practice to the full extent of their education and training.
			 The report also states that all health care professionals should work
			 collaboratively in team-based models, and that the goal should be to
			 encourage care models that use every member of the team to the full
			 capacity of his or her training and skills.
The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
emphasizes the need for
			 improving care and lowering costs by better coordination of care and
			 integration of services, particularly for consumers with multiple chronic
			 conditions. This will require developing new models of care for those
			 receiving long-term services and supports.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding
			 at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Part A of title IV of the Older Americans Act of 1965

header.#text: Demonstration program on care coordination and service delivery
Demonstration program on care coordination and service delivery

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall carry out a demonstration program in accordance with this section.
			 Under such program, the

shall award grants to eligible
			 entities to carry out demonstration projects that focus on care
			 coordination and service delivery redesign for older individuals with
			 chronic illness or at risk of institutional placement by—

text.#text: The

designing and testing new models of care coordination and service delivery that thoughtfully and
			 effectively deploy advanced aides to improve efficiency and quality of
			 care for frail older individuals; and

giving direct-care workers opportunities for career advancement through additional training, an
			 expanded role, and increased compensation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for Home Health Aides [31–1011], Psychiatric Aides
			 [31–1013], Nursing Assistants [31–1014], and Personal Care Aides
			 [39–9021].

term.#tail: has the meaning given that term in the 2010 Standard Occupational Classifications of the

text.#text: In this section, the term
The demonstration program shall be composed of 6 demonstration projects, as follows:

Two demonstration projects shall focus on using the abilities of direct-care workers to promote
			 smooth transitions in care and help to prevent unnecessary hospital
			 readmissions. Under these projects, direct-care workers shall be
			 incorporated as essential members of interdisciplinary care coordination
			 teams.

Two demonstration projects shall focus on maintaining the health and improving the health status of
			 those with multiple chronic conditions and long-term care needs. Under
			 these projects, direct-care workers shall assist in monitoring health
			 status, ensuring compliance with prescribed care, and educating and
			 coaching the older individual involved and any family caregivers.

Two demonstration projects shall focus on training direct-care workers to take on deeper clinical
			 responsibilities related to specific diseases, including Alzheimer’s and
			 dementia, congestive heart failure, and diabetes.

term.#tail: means a consortium that consists of—

entity that provides health services training;

State-based public entity engaged in building new roles and related curricula for direct-care

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: deems eligible based on integrated care criteria.

an application at such time, in such manner, and

may require, which shall

text.#text: To be eligible to receive a grant under this section, an eligible entity shall submit to the

a description of the care coordination and service delivery models of the entity, detailed on a
			 general, organizational, and staff level;

a description of how the demonstration project carried out by the entity will improve care quality,
			 including specific objectives and anticipated outcomes that will be used
			 to measure success; and

a description of how the coordinated care team approach with an enhanced role for the direct-care
			 worker under the demonstration project will increase efficiency and cost
			 effectiveness compared to past practice.

Each eligible entity that receives a grant under this section shall receive a grant for planning
			 activities related to the demonstration project to be carried out by the
			 entity, including—
designing the implementation of the project;

identifying competencies and developing curricula for the training of participating direct-care
			 workers;
developing training materials and processes for other members of the interdisciplinary care team;

articulating a plan for identifying and tracking cost savings gained from implementation of the
			 project and for achieving long-term financial sustainability; and
articulating a plan for evaluating the project.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for all grants shall not exceed $600,000.
